text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with baked eggplant sandwiches
that's right i got a few requests for
fried eggplant for like super bowl
appetizer type stuff which reminded me
of this amazing baked eggplant sandwich
that i had made for years and years and
while it's not exactly fried eggplant it
is superior and that it's stuffed with
salami and cheese so let me show you how
to make these they're a little bit messy
to prepare but very easy and totally
worth it step 1 we're going to slice up
some eggplant a quarter inch is probably
too thin a half inch probably a little
too big so just under a half inch what's
that 3/8 i should've showed you this
using a ruler but i was afraid someone
walk into the kitchen while i was
measuring an eggplant that's a bad look
so nice thick slices just like that and
i know a lot of people like to salt
their eggplant slices to draw out the
bitter liquid and then they rinse them
and dry them we're not doing that not
necessary okay and you can read about
that on the blog too but just slice them
up so once your eggplants cut you're
going to grab a slice you're going to
match it with the slice that was next to
it because we're making little
sandwiches we want these to be as close
in size as possible and yes because
eggplants tapered some of these
sandwiches are going to be a little
larger than others they all should be
the same thickness which is the
important part
but sizes will vary it's all part of the
fun once you have your eggplant all
paired up on the bottom slice you're
going to put a quarter slice of
provolone cheese three thin slices of
salami alright another quarter slice of
provolone and we're intentionally
placing the cheese just in the middle
that will slowly spread out as it cooks
so we don't want it near the edge you're
going to top that with the top half of
the eggplant and that one's prepped all
right so once more with feeling
it's eggplant cheese salami cheese
eggplant all right very simple and by
the way you do not want to overfill
these I know it doesn't look like much
in there but it will be the perfect
proportion you'll see unlike most things
in life restraint is important here okay
so don't over stuff these so once all
your eggplant sandwiches are built you
are ready for the old classic breading
station which is seasoned flour all
right read about that on the blog beaten
egg and some very fine breadcrumbs I
guess you could use panko for this but
I've always used the traditional fine
dry breadcrumb are you going to take one
of your sandwiches you're going to dip
it in the flour on both sides all right
make sure it's coated generously shake
off the excess you're going to dip it
into your
egg mixture alright again make sure it's
coded perfectly alright bread crumb does
not stick to flour it loves to stick to
eggs but not to flour so make sure
that's coated well alright place that in
your breadcrumb pan and I like to use a
spoon to spoon over the bread crumbs so
I keep at least one of my hands dry
alright press that in firmly shake off
the excess and then we're going to place
those on a foil lined baking sheet but
before we do you want to drizzle down a
little bit of olive oil all right couple
teaspoons just like that roughly the
size of the eggplant sandwich place it
down and then drizzle over about the
same amount on top we're going to finish
that with just a little bit of grated
Parmesan cheese very finely grated
alright just a little dusting on each
and then what's going to happen we're
basically going to fry these in the oven
at a high temperature for 25 and what
we'll do is we'll do 10 minutes on this
side we'll flip them over put some more
cheese on give them 10 minutes on that
side and they should be perfect alright
let's test my theory so they go in for
10 minutes all right we're going to flip
them over that she should have glued
both sides together but be careful when
you flip it and you'll see those are
starting to brown nicely and I'm doing
this without a lot of oil the Italians I
learned this from used way more oil but
I don't think you need a ton alright so
you're going to flip those over you're
going to dust that side with Parmesan
cheese we're going to put those back in
the oven for another 8 to 10 minutes
until they're well browned and the
eggplants cooked through look how
gorgeous those are and yes you may have
a little bit of cheese that drips out
the side that's totally normal
alright the French call that leakage du
fromage alright there's nothing to be
afraid of once they come out I usually
flip them over the other side should be
a little browner by the way any of the
cheese did did drip out just push up
against the sandwich it will stick to it
and when it cools you will have bonus
caramelized cheese remnants attached to
your sandwich always a delicious
addition alright I'm going to transfer
those onto a cooling rack and then very
important listen to me now but hear me
later these are not slow speed and hot
these are not even supposed to be warm
these are intended to be eaten
room-temperature why it's an Italian
thing but once they're cooled down to
room temperature go ahead and throw that
on a plate
maybe you're serving it is a lunch with
a little salad and some olives
you're going to cut these in half and
put them on a tray for a party all right
very versatile and incredibly tasty look
at that that's slightly crunchy outside
that soft earthy moist eggplants and
what's not to like about provolone and
salami nothing those things are always
delicious all right and you can see
there even though we only put a few thin
slices
we have plenty of filling and of course
obviously you can use this exact same
technique and fill these with whatever
you want just do not over stuff that's
really the key anyway like I said a
little bit messy to make but not hard at
all and the payoff is very very
worthwhile
all right so I really hope you give
these a try head over to food wishes
comm for all the ingredient amounts and
more info as usual and as always enjoy
